list_definition.definition: weak or trembling with age, illness etc
(sometimes with at) not very good, accurate etc

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He’s a bit shaky at arithmetic
My arithmetic has always been very shaky
I’d be grateful if you would correct my rather shaky spelling.

list_ex_of_english: Both the possibility of forgery and the shaky ground upon which this bank, like many, found itself speak to the extent of widespread economic vulnerability in the period.
Already shaky ministerial chairs now wobble precariously.
The altered body becomes an unknown terrain that must be relearned ; it becomes shaky ground on which a new order - if there is to be order - must be built.
The fire appears to have been put out, but the foundations of our financial system are still shaky.
The first has a rather shaky premise and is somewhat over-determined.
The legal basis for collecting tolls now seems to be on shaky ground.
He has not been watching the sails; we should not follow his shaky course.
The lump is damaging the quality of construction work and is undermining the industry's already shaky collective bargaining machinery.
